In America, the rustbelt usually refers to the area covering the older industrial cities, from New York to Pennsylvania and Ohio, and to the shores of Lake Michigan. These suffered in the late-1970s from a proliferation of rusting factories, declining home prices, population losses, high unemployment, and general economic malaise. Safford (2009, p. 3) noted that it is not clear when exactly the term rustbelt entered the scholarly lexicon, but suggests that its widespread use came during the presidential campaign of 1984 when Walter Mondale criticized Ronald Reagan for turning the industrial Midwest into a “rust bowl”: “Reporters who covered the campaign picked up on the term, transforming it in the course of that campaign into the ‘rust belt.’”

There has been few studies that demonstrate how Japanese local industrial cities have dealt with economic restructuring since the 1980s: for studies dealing with other steel towns, see Wiltshire (1991, 1998) on the city of Kamaishi and Shapira (1993, 1994) on Kitakyushu. For studies of declining coal towns in Japan, see Gilman (1997, 2001) on Omuta and Culter (1999) on Yubari. For the plight of steel mills communities in Europe and North America, see Kunzmann (1986), Hudson (1989), Benhart and Benhart (2000), and Safford (2009).

Technically, endaka involved a rapid appreciation of the yen against the U.S. dollar, which made Japanese exports more expensive. The bubble economy refers to the years 1986-1991, in which real estate and stock prices were greatly inflated. The bubble’s subsequent collapse contributed to what some refer to as the lost decade of the 1990s and the early-2000s due also to the aftermath of Japan’s financial crisis in 1990-1993 together with a liquidity trap and lack of effective consumption (see Hamada, Kashyap, and Weinstein 2011).
Japan’s Ministry of International Trade and Industry (MITI) was reorganized into the Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry (METI) in 2001.

Core employees are those with “insider group” employees with full-time jobs and with long-term employment and career prospects. Brown et al. (1997) noted that there has always been significant qualifications to Japan’s long-term employment model, including the earlier retirement age for the majority of workers at 55 years, the virtual exclusion of women from this system, and the more vulnerable position of temporary workers, part-time workers, and subcontractor workers, who are treated as “outsider groups.” The company union does not usually represent these workers even though they often work alongside regular union employees. Most part-time workers are women and are used to provide flexibility and a “buffer labor force” when adjustments are required in severe recessions.
Monozukuri can be translated as “the art, science or craft of making things,” often traced back to Japan’s early craft traditions (see Pringle 2010).

The most notorious casualty of the new approach was the former coal mining town of Yubari in Hokkaido. Following the collapse of the coal industry in the 1980s, subsidies were obtained initially from the central government and huge debts incurred for the building of tourist attractions, but few visitors came. In 2007, the city was in the news due to bankruptcy and the refusal of the national government to bail it out. City services were severely cut and its white elephant amusement park and museums were put on sale (Mantale, Rausch, and The Shrinking Regions Research Group 2011).

The Hokkaido Development Authority was restructured as the Hokkaido Regional Bureau of the Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism (MLIT) in 2001. The Hokkaido Development Agency as a special agency of the Prime Minister’s office was absorbed in 2001 by the newly formed MLIT.

Hirayama (2009) argued that the success of the Urban Renaissance program in Tokyo was due also to the aggressive promotion by the Governor of the Tokyo Metropolitan Government (TMG), Shintaro Ishihara (1999- ). The TMG felt threatened by the rapid progress and catching up by Asian rivals such as Singapore, Shanghai, and Seoul. Consequently, Governor Ishihara seized the opportunity to upgrade Tokyo’s central core in by encouraging new development using the new central government program.

Reaction to the Urban Renaissance program has been mixed. Thus, Shibata (2008, p. 93) argued that the Japanese state has “vigorously applied neoliberal logic to their planning policy during the last two decades.” Other commentators, such as Waley (2007), tend to agree and suggest that private capital is playing a growing role in the transformation of Tokyo’s urban space. Hirayama (2009), however, considered that the urban renaissance policy has followed a traditional Japanese approach whereby the state has taken the initiative in both policy design and implementation (see also Fujita 2003, 2011; Sorensen, Okata, and Fujii 2010).

Brenner and Theodore (2002, p. 349) contrasted neoliberal ideology with “the contextual embeddedness of neo-liberal restructuring projects insofar as they have been produced within national, regional, and local contexts defined by the legacies of inherited institutional frameworks, policy regimes, regulatory practices, and political struggles.”

The material on which this study was based was collected in field research during 1989, 1992, 1995, 2001, 2005, and 2010. In total, 10 interviews were conducted with staff of the City and the Muroran Techno Centre, two managers of Nippon Steel Corporation (NSC) in Muroran and two central office executives in Tokyo, one steel union official in Tokyo, one government official in Sapporo, two officers of the central government, and five professors at the Muroran Institute of Technology (MIT). Interviews were semistructured and aimed at capturing current policies and programs together with the interactions between various actors.

The NSC was formed by the merger of Yawata Steel (which took over the Wanishi Steel Works in 1934) and Fuji Steel companies in 1970. With the support of Japan’s MITI it became the largest steel company in the world and a national champion favored by the Japanese government with access to funds from the Industrial Bank of Japan. The central government’s role in sponsoring the formation of the NSC would prove important in later years when productive capacity had to be cut back. Essentially, the government felt an obligation to find ways to assist unemployed workers and their communities, both in Muroran and elsewhere (Hart and Kawasaki 1995; Yamawaki 1988). Yonekura (1994) argued that NSC was forced by MITI to keep the almost 100-year-old obsolete facilities in Muroran in operation as compensation for the unprecedented merger in 1970 of Yawata Steel and Fuji Steel, forming Nippon Steel.

Specialty steel manufacturing involves adding rare metal and special heat treatment after the rolling process. This type of steel is developed usually in conjunction with end users to match their specific needs, and has many characteristics (e.g., durability, antiabrasion, and easy processing) on top of basic tensile strength. Typically, this type of steel is used mainly for parts in automobile assembly (e.g., engine parts, industrial springs, gears, and crankshafts), which was an expanding export industry in Japan during the 1970s and 1980s. Specialty steel was not suitable for NSC’s mass-production operations in Kimitsu (Chiba), Nagoya, and Oita (Kyushu) (NSC Muroran Works 1992).

The Special Measures for Recession Affected Regions Law 1978, makes available a range of benefits to potential investors, including special financing from the Japan Development Bank, favored depreciation rates (15-21%), tax exemption in land acquisition, and reduced taxation rates for newly opened factories. In addition, third-sector projects received industrial infrastructure funding, together with loan guarantees for new venture businesses, management, and operational advice (interview with M. Hoshino, Director, Research Exchange, Research Institute of International Trade and Industry, MITI, Tokyo, July 1992).

Part of NSC’s Fourth Rationalization Plan involved diversification of activities away from steel production. Faced with such dramatic and fundamental structural change in both markets and cost structures, it sought new sources of profits. This program of diversification (which also assisted Muroran) was found nationally in engineering, software development, biotechnology, and real estate development by using its substantial land and factory assets, its deep investment capacity, and the wide array of workers’ skills (Noma 1992; NSC 1991a, 1991b).

Following the various transfers of employees to and from Muroran, tracking the exact numbers of workers on the Muroran site became more complex. For instance, the official employment levels recorded by NSC included those already dispatched to other businesses operating under shukko (long-term loan of employees) arrangements (Sato 1996). By 1995, NSC provided estimates to the author that the Muroran Works had about 4,000 employees working at the complex compared with 4,700 in 1985. This comprised roughly 2,000 workers directly involved in steel making, 1,500 in “new” NSC-affiliated firms (including Mitsubishi Seiko), and 500 employed in non-NSC companies invited into the site from elsewhere. About 75% of the latter group were from other parts of the NSC “empire,” or users of NSC specialty steel products from Tokyo, Osaka, and Nagoya that had been attracted to set up their branch operations at the Muroran Works (interview with M. Sugita, Executive Director, Corporate Planning and Restructuring, Nippon Steel, Tokyo, July 1995).
The Ministry of Labor was restructured as the Ministry of Health, Labor and Welfare in 2001.

Closer relations between the MIT and local firms became possible following the restructuring of national universities in 2002 and the need to search for external research funds. By 2005, MIT had conducted more than 100 research projects with local companies and set up joint-venture companies. Examples of MIT-based venture companies included development of biological plants for purification of industrial effluent and the production of mobile batteries (interview with Professor K. Saito, Director, Center for Cooperative Research & Development, MIT, June 2005).

From 2004, the Muroran Port Development Council received central government Urban Renaissance funding under a special “Town-making subsidy scheme” (machi-zukuri kofuin) channeled through the MLIT. In practice, this program involved promotion activities by a local nonprofit organization (NPO) (Compass) taking advantage of port facilities for various cultural and retail market events (MLIT Hokkaido District Transport Bureau 2006; Urban Renaissance Headquarters 2006). All told, they helped to attract an estimated 1.3 million tourists per year by 2010, including summer cruise ships, attracted by the city’s appealing natural environment, especially whale and dolphin watching, its beaches, and mountain lookouts (MLIT Hokkaido District Transport Bureau 2006, 2011; Urban Renaissance Headquarters 2006).

It is not certain whether the neoliberalization of urban and regional policy will further progress in Japan. Following the end of the Koizumi government, successive prime ministers signaled a halt to deregulation, privatization, and spending cuts. After Koizumi left office in 2006, the momentum for neoliberal structural reform in the Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) gradually petered out. None of his successors possessed the same kind of messianic fervor for reform that Koizumi did. The government of Prime Minister Yasuo Fukuda (2007-2008) combined the functions relating to urban renaissance and specified zones for structural reform into one authority. These were combined with other programs geared to tackle the tasks of revitalizing local economies and also reducing the gap between prosperous urban regions and economically weak rural regions (The Japan Times 2007). Later, the government of Prime Minister Taro Aso (2008-2009) engaged in a vote-buying spree in the name of stimulating the economy after the global financial crisis. More than a third of the government’s 2009 supplementary budget was designated to large-scale public works in peripheral regions (Mulgan 2011). At the end of the study period, Prime Minister Yukio Hatayama (2009-2010) of the newly elected Democratic Party of Japan (DJP) also shied away from cutting public works as well as delaying privatizing postal offices and the national postal bank to protect and revitalize rural regions (ibid.).

Interestingly, Hospers (2004, p. 152) noted that the Germany ‘Ruhrgebeit’ rustbelt has also achieved growth through innovation, start-up companies, and local technology transfer centers with a focus on the environmental sector: “The Ruhr has grown into the centre of environmental technology research in Germany” employing about 100,000 people.

bio.title: Author Biography
bio.p: David W. Edgington is a professor in the Department of Geography, University of British Columbia. His teaching and research interests include aspects of economic and urban geography in the Asia-Pacific region, such as Japanese trade and investment patterns in East Asia, urban and regional change in Japan, Japanese tourism in Canada, and multicultural planning in cities of Pacific Rim countries. He is the author of Reconstructing Kobe: The Geography of Crisis and Opportunity (UBC Press, 2010).
